questions.text: Nadas criteria include all of the following except: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Raised Trop T level

 

Nadas criteria, proposed by Hungarian cardiologist Dr. Alexander Nadas in the 1950s–60s, are used for diagnosing congenital heart disease. The criteria require at least one major and two minor criteria for diagnosis. Major criteria include systolic murmur grade 3-4/6, diastolic murmur, presence of congestive heart failure, and cyanosis. Minor criteria include grade 2/6 systolic murmur, abnormal S2, abnormal chest X-ray, abnormal ECG, and abnormal blood pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nadas criteria are used for diagnosing congenital heart disease, which includes both major criteria (systolic murmur grade 3-4/6, diastolic murmur, CCF, cyanosis) and minor criteria (grade 2/6 systolic murmur, abnormal S2, abnormal X-ray, abnormal ECG, abnormal BP).

choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with edema and anasarca. A diagnosis of minimal change disease is made. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Good response to steroids

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is a type of glomerulonephritis that typically affects children and is characterized by the presence of nephrotic syndrome. The following statement is true about this condition:

 

  • Good response to steroids: MCD is often considered to be the most steroid-responsive form of nephrotic syndrome. The vast majority of children with MCD respond well to treatment with corticosteroids, with complete remission of proteinuria and edema occurring in over 90% of cases. However, the response to steroids may be less predictable in adults with MCD.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes: Electron microscopy shows nonspecific obliteration of epithelial foot processes (not light microscopy)

 

Option C. Most common in adults: it is common in pediatric age group, not adults

 

Option D. Non-selective proteinuria: the patient will have massive nephrotic range proteinuria.

 

The causes of MCD are mostly idiopathic. It is usually associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma (due to the increased production of cytokines), respiratory infections, prophylactic immunizations, eczema, and rhinitis.

 

 

Clinically, they mostly present with proteinuria. The child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalized edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and has a very good response to corticosteroid treatment, resulting in complete remission of proteinuria and edema in over 90% of cases.

questions.text: A patient presented with a renal stone after a Proteus infection. What is the likely composition of the stone in him? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Magnesium ammonium phosphate

 

Proteus infections are caused by urease-positive organisms that produce urease, an enzyme that breaks down urea into ammonia, leading to alkaline urine. The alkaline environment facilitates the formation of struvite stones, also known as magnesium ammonium phosphate stones or staghorn calculi.

 

These stones are associated with urinary tract infections, especially those caused by urease-positive bacteria like Proteus species.

 

Struvite stones are characterized by their unique "staghorn" appearance, where they form large, branching stones that fill the renal pelvis and calyces. These stones are radiopaque, which means they can be easily detected on a plain X-ray.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium phosphate: While calcium phosphate stones can form in alkaline urine, they are not specifically associated with infections by urease-producing bacteria like Proteus. These stones are more commonly linked to other metabolic abnormalities.

 

Option C. Xanthine: Xanthine stones are rare and typically form due to a genetic defect in purine metabolism, unrelated to infections or urinary pH changes. They do not form as a result of Proteus infection.

 

Option D. Cysteine: Cysteine stones are associated with cystinuria, a genetic disorder that leads to excessive cysteine in the urine. These stones typically form in acidic urine and have a distinct hexagonal crystal appearance, unrelated to Proteus infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Magnesium ammonium phosphate (struvite) stones are commonly formed in alkaline urine due to urease-positive bacterial infections, such as those caused by Proteus. They often present as staghorn calculi filling the renal pelvis and calyces.

questions.text: Identify the anomaly seen on the ultrasound. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anencephaly

 

The ultrasound image shows a characteristic "frog face" appearance, which is highly indicative of anencephaly. Anencephaly is a severe congenital condition where a major portion of the brain, skull, and scalp is absent. This condition can be identified as early as 12 to 14 weeks of gestation via ultrasound. The typical appearance on the ultrasound includes the absence of the cranial vault and cerebral hemispheres, resulting in the recognizable frog-like appearance of the fetus’s head.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Encephalocele: This is incorrect. Encephalocele is a neural tube defect characterized by a sac-like protrusion of the brain and membranes through an opening in the skull. It does not present with the “frog face” appearance.

 

Option C. Lissencephaly: This is incorrect. Lissencephaly is a brain malformation characterized by the absence of normal brain folds (gyri) and is not associated with the absence of the skull or the typical features seen in the image.

 

Option D. Holoprosencephaly: This is incorrect. Holoprosencephaly involves the failure of the brain to divide into two hemispheres and has a different ultrasound appearance, often showing facial anomalies like a single eye or cleft palate, but not the frog-like appearance seen in anencephaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anencephaly presents on ultrasound with a distinct "frog face" appearance due to the absence of the cranial vault and cerebral hemispheres. It can be diagnosed early in pregnancy, typically around 12 to 14 weeks.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the following MRI scan:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cerebellum

 

Explanation:

 

The given image shows an MRI of the sagittal section of the brain, where the red arrow points to the Cerebellum. This part of the brain is known for its role in motor control, and it can also be involved in some cognitive functions like attention and language.

 

Key features visible in the MRI that help identify the Cerebellum include its characteristic lobulated structure located at the posterior base of the brain, just below the cerebrum and behind the brainstem and fourth ventricle.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Midbrain: Part of the brainstem, located higher and anteriorly relative to the cerebellum on sagittal images.

 

Option C. Brainstem: The brainstem, which includes the midbrain, pons, and medulla, is located anteriorly to the cerebellum in the image.

 

Option D. Cerebrum: The largest part of the brain, covering most of the upper sections of the image, involved in various higher-order functions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Cerebellum, distinct in its appearance and location in the posterior aspect of the brain, plays crucial roles in the coordination of voluntary movements and motor functions, which can be clearly seen on sagittal MRI scans.

questions.text: The 190 kDa BCR-ABL protein is most commonly associated with: (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. ALL

 

Explanation: 

 

The 190 kDa BCR-ABL protein is most commonly associated with B-cell Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (B-ALL). This specific form of the BCR-ABL fusion protein results from the Philadelphia chromosome t(9;22). While BCR-ABL is also found in Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML), the size of the protein is different. In B-ALL, the BCR-ABL protein is usually 190 kDa in size, whereas in CML, a BCR-ABL protein of 210 kDa is typically present. The 190 kDa variant has stronger tyrosine kinase activity than the 210 kDa form and is strongly associated with a subset of B-ALL.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. AML - This is incorrect. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML) is not typically associated with the BCR-ABL fusion protein. AML is characterized by different genetic abnormalities including t(8;21), inv(16), and t(15;17).

 

Option C. CML - This is incorrect. While CML is associated with the BCR-ABL fusion protein, it is typically the 210 kDa form rather than the 190 kDa form. The 210 kDa BCR-ABL protein results from a different breakpoint in the BCR gene.

 

Option D. CLL - This is incorrect. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) is not associated with BCR-ABL fusion proteins. CLL is characterized by other genetic abnormalities including deletions of 13q14.3, 11q, and 17p, and trisomy 12q.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The 190 kDa BCR-ABL fusion protein is specifically associated with Philadelphia chromosome-positive B-ALL, while the 210 kDa variant is found in CML; this difference in molecular weight reflects different breakpoints in the BCR gene and results in proteins with different tyrosine kinase activities.

questions.text: The transfer of genetic information between DNA molecules inside a cell is called: (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A. Transposition

 

Explanation:

 

Transposition is the correct answer because it refers to the movement of DNA segments called transposons ("jumping genes") between different DNA molecules within the same cell. Transposons are discrete segments of DNA that can move from one location to another in a "cut-and-paste" manner between chromosomal and extrachromosomal DNA molecules inside a bacterial cell.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Transformation - This is the transfer of genetic information through free or naked DNA from the environment into a bacterial cell. It involves uptake of external DNA, not transfer between DNA molecules already inside a cell.

 

Option C. Conjugation - This involves the transfer of genetic material from one bacterium (donor or male) to another (recipient or female) through direct physical contact (through a sex pilus). It is a process of transfer between different cells, not between DNA molecules inside the same cell.

 

Option D. Duplication - This refers to the replication of DNA during cell division, where the entire DNA molecule is copied. It does not involve transfer of genetic segments between different DNA molecules.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transposons (mobile genetic elements) facilitate genetic diversity within a cell by moving DNA segments between chromosomal and plasmid DNA. This mechanism of transposition can lead to the acquisition of new characteristics by bacteria, including antibiotic resistance.

choices.text: Left axis deviation
Mild ST changes in inferior leads
Atrial and ventricular premature contractions
Pansystolic murmur

questions.text: All are normal physiological changes in pregnancy except? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pansystolic murmur

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, there are several physiological changes in the cardiovascular system:

 

  1. Clinical Examination:
    • Jugular venous distension and venous hum are commonly observed.
    • Mammary soufflé: A continuous murmur can be heard at the 2nd to 4th intercostal spaces.
    • Flow murmurs at the aortic or pulmonary areas.
    • Increased and widely split S1 sound.
    • S2 P component is increased, and S2 is split.
    • The apex beat is shifted to the 4th intercostal space, 2.5 cm outside the mid-clavicular line.
  2. Electrocardiography:
    • T wave inversion and bi-atrial enlargement.
    • Various dysrhythmias, including atrial and ventricular premature contractions, are relatively frequent.
    • Due to the diaphragm being elevated during advancing pregnancy, there is an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the electrocardiogram (ECG), and mild ST changes may be seen in the inferior leads.
    • Pregnancy does not alter voltage.
    • Tricuspid regurgitation may be present.
    • Increased left atrial end-diastolic dimension and left ventricular mass.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left axis deviation: This is a normal change due to the diaphragm being elevated during pregnancy, causing an average 15-degree left-axis deviation in the ECG.

 

Option B. Mild ST changes in inferior leads: These are normal and can be seen due to the changes in heart position and function during pregnancy.

 

Option C. Atrial and ventricular premature contractions: These are relatively frequent and considered normal in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diastolic and pansystolic murmurs in pregnancy are not normal and should be investigated further.

 

Ref: Page 178, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare
Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change
Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment

questions.text: Which is the Nodal Ministry for Disaster Management? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ministry of Home Affairs

 

The Ministry of Home Affairs is the nodal ministry for disaster management in India. The National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA) functions under the Ministry of Home Affairs, with the Prime Minister serving as its chairperson. The nodal center for disaster management is at the district level.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Ministry of Health and Family Welfare: While this ministry plays a role in health-related aspects of disasters, it is not the nodal ministry for overall disaster management.

 

Option C. Ministry of Environment, Forests and Climate Change: This ministry deals with environmental aspects but is not responsible for coordinating disaster management activities.

 

Option D. Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment: This ministry focuses on social welfare programs but does not coordinate disaster management activities.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Ministry of Home Affairs serves as the nodal ministry for disaster management in India, with the district being the nodal center for implementation. NDMA functions under the Ministry of Home Affairs with the Prime Minister as its chairperson.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with a history of HTN, DM2, and DLP is brought to the ER because of reports of palpitations and dizziness. ECG is ordered and shown in the image. His temperature is 36.8°C, PR is 106/min, RR is 18/min, BP is 84/46 mm Hg, and SpO2 is 92% on room air. What is the next step? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. DC shock

 

The patient presents with symptoms of palpitations and dizziness and is found to have an irregularly irregular rhythm on ECG, consistent with atrial fibrillation (AF). The absence of distinct P waves and the presence of fibrillatory waves further support this diagnosis.

 

The patient's vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 84/46 mm Hg, indicating hemodynamic instability. In cases of tachyarrhythmias such as AF, the management approach depends on the patient's hemodynamic status. For patients who are hemodynamically unstable, immediate intervention is required.

 

Synchronized DC cardioversion is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically unstable patients with AF. This procedure involves delivering a synchronized shock to restore normal rhythm. The shock is timed (synchronized) to occur at the peak of the R wave to avoid inducing ventricular fibrillation.

 

Specific contraindications for using synchronized direct current (DC) cardioversion (synchronized DC shocking) are sinus tachycardia, multifocal atrial tachycardia digoxin toxicity. But in cases where a patient is unstable and experiencing shock, immediate cardioversion is necessary despite these contraindications, underscoring the urgency in treating life-threatening arrhythmias in acute settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heparin: Heparin is an anticoagulant used to prevent thromboembolic events in patients with AF. However, it is not the immediate intervention of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients. The priority in such cases is to stabilize the patient's condition, which requires electrical cardioversion.

 

Option B. Beta blocker: Beta blockers are used to control the heart rate in AF. They are not appropriate for initial management in an unstable patient, as they do not address the immediate need to restore a stable rhythm.

 

Option C. Amiodarone: Amiodarone is an antiarrhythmic that can be used in the management of AF. However, it is typically used in stable patients or after electrical cardioversion has been attempted. In an unstable patient, immediate electrical cardioversion is preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In hemodynamically unstable patients with atrial fibrillation, immediate synchronized DC cardioversion is the next step to restore a stable rhythm and improve hemodynamic status.

questions.text: Which of the following is the method to prevent febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reaction?  (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leucodepleted blood

 

Explanation:

 

Febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions (FNHTRs) are caused by antibodies in the recipient's plasma reacting with the donor's white blood cells (leukocytes) present in the transfused blood. The use of leucodepleted blood, which has been filtered to remove most of the leukocytes, significantly reduces the risk of FNHTRs by eliminating the trigger for the antibody reaction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prophylactic paracetamol may help in managing fever if an FNHTR occurs, but it does not prevent the reaction itself.

 

Option B. Intravenous steroids are not typically used for the prevention of FNHTRs. Steroids may be administered in cases of severe transfusion reactions, but they do not specifically target the underlying cause of FNHTRs.

 

Option D. Saline-washed red cell transfusion is a method used to reduce the risk of allergic reactions due to the presence of plasma proteins, but it does not directly address the issue of FNHTRs caused by leukocyte antibodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The use of leucodepleted blood, which has been filtered to remove most of the donor's white blood cells, is the recommended method to prevent febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions caused by antibody reactions against the transfused leukocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following types of renal stones are produced by laxative abuse? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ammonium urate

 

Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse.

 

Ammonium urate stones are composed of a combination of ammonia and uric acid. When laxatives are abused, they cause metabolic alkalosis. This alkaline environment can lead to the formation of ammonium urate stones, as ammonium is more soluble in alkaline urine than in acidic urine.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uric acid: Uric acid stones form when the urine is persistently acidic, which can occur in conditions like gout or diseases that cause rapid cell turnover like tumor lysis syndrome. A diet high in purines, certain types of medications, and some genetic factors can contribute to uric acid stone formation. However, these stones are not typically associated with laxative abuse.

 

Option C. Struvite: Struvite stones, also known as infection stones, are associated with urinary tract infections caused by certain bacteria. These bacteria can produce urease, which splits urea in to ammonia, that makes the urine more alkaline, which can lead to struvite stone formation. They are not directly associated with laxative abuse.

 

Option D. Calcium oxalate: Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stone. Factors that increase the urine concentration of these constituents can contribute to stone formation. The absorption of oxalate might increase with chronic diarrhea (a potential consequence of laxative abuse), which can contribute to the formation of calcium oxalate stones, however this is not a common feature.

 

Educational Objective:


Laxative abuse can lead to metabolic alkalosis, which creates an alkaline urinary environment, predisposing to the formation of ammonium urate stones.

choices.text: Motor speech area
Wernicke's area
Auditory area

questions.text: A lady presents with vascular injury to the inferior frontal gyrus. Which functional area is likely to be affected? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Motor speech area

 

Explanation

 

  • Broca's motor speech area is likely to be affected in the vascular injury of the inferior frontal gyrus
  • Broca area is the motor area for speech. It includes areas 44 and 45. Broca area is present in left hemisphere (dominant hemisphere) of right-handed persons and in the right hemisphere of left-handed persons.
  • It is a special region of premotor cortex situated in inferior frontal gyrus. Area 44 is situated in pars triangularis and 45 in pars opercularis of this gyrus.
  • Broca aphasia is the non-fluent speech problem. It occurs due to lesion in left frontal lobe of cerebral cortex. It is also known as expressive aphasia or anterior aphasia. The affected persons do not complete the sentences because of their inability to construct the sentences. They often talk in short phrases by omitting small words such as ‘and’, ‘is’, ‘for’, etc. They make great efforts even to initiate speech. Persons with Broca aphasia are able to understand spoken or written words.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's area: Incorrect. Wernicke's area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the temporal lobe, not the inferior frontal gyrus. It is responsible for the comprehension of speech and language.

 

Option C. Auditory area: Incorrect. The primary auditory cortex is located in the superior temporal gyrus of the temporal lobe, which is involved in processing auditory information.

 

Option D. Visual area: Incorrect. The primary visual cortex is located in the occipital lobe, which is primarily responsible for processing visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Injury to the inferior frontal gyrus is likely to impact Broca's area, leading to deficits in motor speech production known as Broca's aphasia. This condition manifests as difficulty in speech articulation and sentence construction, significantly affecting verbal communication despite preserved comprehension.

questions.text: ADH acts through which aquaporin channel?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 2

 

Antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, plays a crucial role in regulating water balance in the body by concentrating urine. It acts primarily through the aquaporin-2 (AQP-2) channels located in the kidney's collecting ducts. Here is how ADH functions:

 

  1. Receptor Interaction: ADH binds to V2 receptors on the basolateral membranes of cells in the late distal convoluted tubules, collecting tubules, and collecting ducts of the kidney.
  2. Signal Transduction: The binding of ADH to these receptors activates the cyclic AMP (cAMP) pathway, leading to the activation of protein kinase A (PKA).
  3. Aquaporin-2 Mobilization: PKA then phosphorylates specific proteins that lead to the translocation of AQP-2 water channels from intracellular storage vesicles to the apical membrane of the kidney cells.
  4. Water Reabsorption: Once inserted into the membrane, AQP-2 channels allow water to be reabsorbed from the tubular fluid back into the bloodstream, thereby concentrating the urine.
  5. Regulation by ADH Levels: Chronic high levels of ADH enhance the synthesis of AQP-2 channels through increased gene transcription, while low levels lead to the internalization of these channels, reducing water reabsorption.

 

Clinical Relevance:

 

In conditions such as nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, there is a genetic mutation that affects the V2 receptors or the AQP-2 channels themselves, rendering the kidney tubules unresponsive to ADH. This results in the inability to concentrate urine and excessive urine output.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aquaporin 1: Incorrect, as AQP-1 is primarily involved in passive water transport in other parts of the kidney and other tissues, not under the control of ADH.

 

Option C. Aquaporin 3 and Option D. Aquaporin 4: Both are incorrect as these aquaporins are located in the basolateral membrane of collecting duct cells and are involved in water transport but are not the primary channels through which ADH acts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ADH specifically regulates the body's water balance by acting through aquaporin-2 channels in the kidney's collecting ducts, facilitating the reabsorption of water back into the bloodstream and thus concentrating the urine. This mechanism is crucial for maintaining proper hydration and electrolyte balance in the body.

choices.text: Pre- invasive diagnostic test

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant woman at 13 weeks of gestation informs you about accidental exposure to radiation from a chest X-ray at 7 weeks of gestation. What should be the next step advised to her? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue pregnancy

 

Explanation

 

  • The risks for malformations, growth restriction, or abortion are not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).
  • Since diagnostic X-rays seldom exceed 0.1 Gy (10 rads), the risk is negligible. A 0.1 Gy exposure is equivalent to more than 1000 chest X-rays.
  • Hence, continuing pregnancy is the most appropriate advice to this woman.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Terminate pregnancy: Termination is not necessary as the radiation dose from a single chest X-ray is significantly lower than the threshold for increased risks.

 

Option C. Pre-invasive diagnostic test: This is not required in this scenario as the radiation dose is too low to justify invasive diagnostics.

 

Option D. Chromosome screening: Chromosome screening is unnecessary because the radiation dose from a chest X-ray does not significantly increase the risk of chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective

 

The risk for fetal malformations, growth restriction, or abortion is not increased from a radiation dose of less than 0.05 Gy (5 rads).

 

Ref: Page 2265, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

choices.text: Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia
Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia, Deep fascia and a few muscular fibers

questions.text: Identify the correct order of layers incised while performing a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Skin, Subcutaneous tissue, Superficial fascia and Deep fascia

 

The incision for a fasciotomy involves the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia.

 

  • Deep fascia is a dense connective tissue layer that surrounds muscles, bones, and neurovascular structures. It creates the compartments in limbs, and in compartment syndrome, it is this fascial layer that is primarily responsible for the elevated pressures.
  • For a fasciotomy, the incision goes through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and, crucially, the deep fascia. This releases the increased pressure in the muscle compartment and restores blood flow.
  • The procedure is best carried out via longitudinal incisions of skin, subcutaneous fat, and superficial and deep fascia.
  • The lower limb can be decompressed via two incisions, each being lateral to the subcutaneous border of the tibia.
  • This gives access to the two posterior compartments and to the peroneal and anterior compartments of the leg.

 

 

Educational Objective:


During a fasciotomy for compartment syndrome, the incision must pass through the skin, subcutaneous tissue, superficial fascia, and deep fascia to adequately decompress the affected muscle compartments.

questions.text: Identify the papillae from the given histological section: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Circumvallate

 

  • The given histological image is a section of the tongue displaying circumvallate papillae, which are the largest papillae present on the tongue.
  • They are cylindrical in shape, and usually around 8-12 in no.
  • They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium and are arranged in a V-shaped row immediately in front of the sulcus terminalis on the dorsal surface of the tongue.
  • They are narrower at their base than their apex and contain numerous taste buds (around 250 for each papilla) within their walls. These taste buds contain chemosensory cells that synapse with the gustatory nerves, enabling the sense of taste.
  • In addition, the serous glands of von Ebner empty via ducts into the base of the sulcus, which helps to flush out food particles from the area surrounding the papillae.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Fungiform papillae are protrusions on the tongue that are relatively large, round, and reddish in color. They can be found on both the dorsal surface and the lingual margins of the tongue, and are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

Option C: Filiform papillae are small, conical or cylindrical projections located mainly on the dorsal surface of the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. They lack taste buds and are covered by keratinized stratified squamous epithelium. All other papillae, except filiform, contain taste buds.

 

Option D: Foliate papillae are red, leaf-like mucosal ridges located bilaterally in two zones at the sides of the tongue near the sulcus terminalis. They are covered by non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Circumvallate papilla are located on the dorsum of the tongue, forming a V-shaped row in front of the terminal sulcus (the V-shaped groove that separates the anterior two-thirds from the posterior third of the tongue). They are the largest papillae, about 8-12 in number, and have a round, raised shape. Each is surrounded by a trench (or moat), hence the name 'circumvallate.

questions.text: A man wears female heels and a female dress to get sexual arousal. He is not interested in males. What is the diagnosis ? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic Fetishism

 

Transvestic Fetishism is a condition where an individual wears clothing of the opposite sex primarily to achieve sexual arousal. The key aspect of this disorder is the act of cross-dressing for the purpose of sexual gratification, not because of a desire to be of the opposite gender or any issues with gender identity. The patient described is not interested in males and is engaging in cross-dressing purely for sexual arousal, fitting the diagnosis of Transvestic Fetishism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender Dysphoria involves a conflict between an individual’s biological sex and their gender identity, such as a biologically male person identifying as female or vice versa. There is no indication in this case of any gender identity issues; the patient cross-dresses purely for sexual arousal.

 

Option C. Homosexuality: Homosexuality refers to a sexual orientation characterized by attraction to individuals of the same sex. The scenario explicitly states that the man is not interested in males, ruling out homosexuality as the correct diagnosis.

 

Option D. Voyeurism: Voyeurism is the act of gaining sexual pleasure from watching others when they are naked or engaged in sexual activity, usually without their knowledge or consent. There is no element of voyeuristic behavior described in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic Fetishism is characterized by cross-dressing for sexual arousal without any associated desire to change one’s gender or sexual orientation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most frequently occurring Occiput-posterior position? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Right Occiput-posterior

 

Right Occiput-posterior (ROP) is the most common occiput posterior position. ROP is more common than left occipito-posterior (LOP) because the left oblique diameter is reduced by the presence of sigmoid colon. In fact, Right occiput posterior is five times more common than the left occiput posterior. Dextrorotation of the uterus and the presence of the sigmoid colon on the left disfavor LOP position.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Direct Occiput-posterior: This is less common than ROP. Direct occiput posterior occurs when the occiput rotates 1/8 circle posteriorly following short arc rotation in cases of marked deflexion.

 

Option C. Left Occiput-posterior: While LOP does occur, it is significantly less common than ROP. ROP is five times more common than LOP due to the presence of the sigmoid colon on the left side.

 

Option D. Indirect Occiput-posterior: This is not a standard classification of occiput posterior positions. The positions are classified as left, right, or direct occiput posterior.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Right occipito-posterior position is the most common OP position, occurring five times more frequently than left occipito-posterior, primarily due to anatomical factors including the presence of the sigmoid colon on the left side and dextrorotation of the uterus.

questions.text: Exclusive breastfeeding is done for? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6 months

 

Explanation:

 

Exclusive breastfeeding is recommended for the first 6 months of a baby's life. During this period, the infant receives only breast milk without any additional food or drink, not even water. Breast milk provides all the essential nutrients, antibodies, and hydration needed for optimal growth and development during these first crucial months. The World Health Organization (WHO) and other health authorities strongly advocate for exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months due to its significant health benefits for both the baby and the mother.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exclusive breastfeeding should be practiced for the first 6 months of a baby's life to ensure they receive optimal nutrition and immune support.

choices.text: An HLA identical matched unrelated donor who is blood type O-
His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

questions.text: A 47-year-old man with a diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia with a blood type O negative blood group presents to the transplant clinic to discuss proceeding with an allogeneic stem cell transplant. Which of the following would be an optimal donor? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. His HLA identical 50-year-old brother who is otherwise healthy and is blood type O+

 

  1. Due to the decreased risk of graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) with related transplants, related donor transplants are still favored over unrelated donor transplants.
  2. Rh incompatibility has no impact on the success of transplants (Rh antigen is only found on the surface of RBCs, not on the parenchymal cells of the graft).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Syngeneic transplantation (donation from identical twins) has been shown to increase the risk of relapse in cases of hematologic malignancies and is therefore not a source of donor that is advised.

 

Option B: Umbilical cord transplant is not usually recommended.

 

Option C: While ABO compatibility is vital when selecting a donor, this is merely a slight ABO discrepancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a patient with acute myeloid leukemia, the optimal donor choice would generally be an HLA identical sibling, despite any ABO blood type differences, due to the lower risk of complications and better overall survival outcomes. Blood type discrepancies, especially in Rh factor, are manageable in the context of stem cell transplants.

 

Reference - Harrison/Transplant/Chap 104

questions.text: Diagnose the image seen in a 10-year-old child. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Herbert pits

 

Herbert pits are depressions seen on the cornea, typically found in patients with trachoma, a chronic infectious disease caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. These pits are formed when the follicles, which are lymphocyte aggregates, present at the limbus (called Herbert follicles) rupture or degenerate, leaving behind characteristic pits. This condition is commonly seen in individuals with trachoma who have chronic eye rubbing due to persistent irritation.

 

Other findings of trachoma are –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horner Trantas spots: These are white, elevated, gelatinous spots seen at the limbus, usually associated with vernal keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), an allergic condition of the eye. They are composed of eosinophils and epithelial cells and are not associated with depressions on the cornea.

 

 

Other findings of VKC are –

 

 

Giant papillae, also known as the cobblestone appearance

 

 

Ropey discharge (Maxwell-Leon sign)

 

Option C. Pannus: Pannus is the growth of abnormal blood vessels into the cornea, often accompanied by fibrovascular tissue. This condition is typically seen in trachoma but presents as vascularization rather than depressions.

 

 

Option D. Corneal dystrophy: This refers to a group of genetic disorders that cause the accumulation of abnormal material in the cornea. Corneal dystrophies present with clouding, swelling, or other structural changes in the cornea, not with pits or depressions.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Herbert pits are characteristic depressions found in the cornea due to the rupture of follicles, commonly seen in trachoma.

choices.text: Mass as shown should be removed
Mass should be reduced by a surgical procedure and mesh repair should be done
Mass should be reduced and anatomical repair by suturing the abdominal wall defect should be done
Mass should be reduced, mesh repair done and the redundant skin should be excised

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the patient who presented with the following as shown in the image. Earlier the abdominal mass was reducible, but now it has become irreducible? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Mass should be reduced, mesh repair done and the redundant skin should be excised

 

The patient presents with an irreducible umbilical or para-umbilical hernia, as indicated by the previously reducible abdominal mass that has now become irreducible. This condition necessitates surgical intervention. The correct management involves reducing the hernia, repairing the defect with a mesh to prevent recurrence, and excising the redundant skin, especially if it appears stretched, unhealthy, or ulcerated. This comprehensive approach ensures both the structural repair and the removal of any compromised skin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mass as shown should be removed: Simply removing the mass without addressing the hernia repair and the redundant skin does not resolve the underlying issue and may lead to recurrence or complications.

 

Option B. Mass should be reduced by a surgical procedure and mesh repair should be done: While this option addresses the hernia reduction and repair, it does not consider the removal of unhealthy or redundant skin, which is necessary in cases of long-standing hernias with poor skin quality.

 

Option C. Mass should be reduced and anatomical repair by suturing the abdominal wall defect should be done: Anatomical repair alone, without the use of mesh, is less effective for ventral hernias and has a higher risk of recurrence. Mesh repair is the standard approach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an irreducible umbilical or para-umbilical hernia, the recommended treatment includes hernia reduction, mesh repair, and excision of redundant or unhealthy skin to ensure a durable and effective repair.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient presents with chin protrusion, excessive sweating, impaired glucose tolerance, and hand and foot enlargement. What is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pegvisomant

 

The patient's symptoms suggest acromegaly, a condition characterized by excessive growth hormone (GH) secretion, usually due to a pituitary adenoma. Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly. It blocks the effects of growth hormone at the receptor level, leading to decreased levels of insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1), which is responsible for the acromegaly symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Octreotide: Octreotide is a somatostatin analogue, which can be used in the treatment of acromegaly. It works by inhibiting the release of growth hormone from the pituitary gland. However, it is not a growth hormone receptor antagonist; instead, it reduces GH secretion.

 

Option C. Cabergoline: Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist primarily used in the treatment of prolactinomas, another type of pituitary adenoma. It is not typically used as a first-line treatment for acromegaly and does not act as a growth hormone receptor antagonist.

 

Option D. Olcegepant: Olcegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide receptor antagonist used in the research for migraine treatment. It is not used in the treatment of acromegaly or related to growth hormone activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat acromegaly by blocking the effects of growth hormone at the receptor level, thereby reducing the symptoms associated with elevated growth hormone levels.

questions.text: Which disease the girl is related to and what's her name? [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Sapna, Leprosy


The girl in the image is named Sapna, and she is associated with the National Leprosy Eradication Program. Sapna is an emblematic figure used to raise awareness about leprosy prevention and control through information, education, and communication (IEC) strategies. She symbolizes the message that leprosy is completely curable. Sapna herself is portrayed as a former leprosy patient who has been fully cured, aiming to reduce stigma and educate the public about the disease's curability.

 

National Leprosy Mission Trust of India is the agency who came out with the concept of the girl Sapna for Leprosy Awareness Efforts Generation.

 

Educational Objective:


Sapna is a character created to promote leprosy awareness and emphasize that leprosy is a 100% curable disease.

choices.text: NPO initially to avoid pancreatic stimulation
Enteral nutrition should be considered 2-3 days after admission in pancreatitis instead of total parenteral nutrition
Early initiation of oral feeds in mild acute pancreatitis

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic male presented to the emergency with sudden onset of abdominal pain radiating to the back, which is aggravated on lying down. Serum amylase and lipase levels are elevated. Which of the following should be avoided in managing the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Infusion of 5% Dextrose

 

Explanation

 

The patient is presenting with signs and symptoms of acute pancreatitis, a condition confirmed by elevated serum amylase and lipase levels.

 

Infusion of 5% Dextrose: This should be avoided in managing acute pancreatitis. Patients often experience hyperglycemia, and the administration of dextrose could worsen this condition. Preferred intravenous fluids for rehydration and initial resuscitation in acute pancreatitis are normal saline (NS) or Ringer's lactate (RL).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. NPO initially to avoid pancreatic stimulation: Keeping the patient NPO (nothing by mouth) is crucial to avoid stimulating the pancreas and exacerbating the condition.

 

Option C. Enteral nutrition should be considered 2-3 days after admission in pancreatitis instead of total parenteral nutrition: This is correct. Early enteral nutrition is preferred over total parenteral nutrition as it helps maintain gut integrity and reduce the risk of infection.

 

Option D. Early initiation of oral feeds in mild acute pancreatitis: This is also correct. For mild cases, early reintroduction of oral feeding is beneficial.

 

Educational Objectives:

 

In the management of acute pancreatitis, avoid the infusion of 5% dextrose due to the risk of exacerbating hyperglycemia.

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) T cell

 

Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell.

 

A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant from a donor of a different species.

 

Nude mice lack body hair, hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T cells and cytotoxic T cells. The absence of functioning T cells also prevents the rejection of allografts & xenografts.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. B cell: Incorrect because the primary immunodeficiency in nude mice relates to T cells, not B cells. While B cells are essential for antibody production, their presence does not compensate for the lack of T cell-mediated immunity necessary for xenograft rejection.

 

Option C. Both B and T cell: Incorrect as nude mice specifically lack T cells due to the absence of a thymus, while B cell function remains intact.

 

Option D. INK cell: Incorrect because the term should likely refer to "NK cells" (natural killer cells), which are not the primary reason for the lack of xenograft rejection in nude mice. NK cells can participate in innate immune responses but do not compensate for the lack of adaptive immune responses mediated by T cells in this context.

 

Educational Objective:


Nude mice lack a thymus, resulting in a deficiency of mature T cells, which are essential for rejecting xenografts. This highlights the crucial role of T cells in adaptive immune responses and graft rejection.

choices.text: Increased fluid intake
Small frequent meals

questions.text: Vomiting in pregnancy is managed by? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Small frequent meals

 

Vomiting in pregnancy, often referred to as morning sickness, can be managed by recommending small, frequent meals. This approach helps to stabilize blood sugar levels and reduces the likelihood of nausea. Eating small amounts of food more frequently can prevent the stomach from becoming too full or too empty, both of which can trigger nausea and vomiting.

 

DOC – Doxylamine combined with Pyridoxine (B6).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Domperidone: While domperidone is used for nausea and vomiting, it is not the drug of choice for managing vomiting in pregnancy. The preferred pharmacological treatment is a combination of doxylamine and pyridoxine.

 

Option B. Increased fluid intake: While staying hydrated is important, increasing fluid intake alone is not the primary management strategy for vomiting in pregnancy. It may be difficult for pregnant women experiencing severe nausea to tolerate large amounts of fluids.

 

Option D. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy): This is not a management option for vomiting in pregnancy. MTP is a procedure for terminating a pregnancy and is unrelated to managing nausea and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Managing vomiting in pregnancy is best achieved by advising small, frequent meals to help stabilize blood sugar levels and reduce nausea.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Earache

 

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.

 

Tuberculosis of the ear

 

  •  Aetiology - Secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis.
  •  Pathology - The process is slow and insidious. Tubercles appear in the submucosal layers of middle ear cleft and caseate. There is painless necrosis of the tympanic membrane. Multiple perforations may form which coalesce to form a single large perforation. Middle ear and mastoid get filled with pale granulations.
  • Clinical features - Painless foul smelling ear discharge, multiple perforations, hearing loss. Mastoiditis, facial paralysis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis with formation of bony sequestra are often seen in these cases.
  •  Treatment - Antitubercular treatment + Mastoidectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple perforations - A characteristic feature of the disease, representing advanced tissue damage.

 

Option C. Pale granulation - These are typical findings within the affected structures.

 

Option D. Foul smelling ear discharge - A hallmark symptom of tubercular otitis media due to the extensive necrosis and infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Earache is notably absent in tubercular otitis media, differentiating it from other types of middle ear infections where pain is a common symptom. Recognizing the painless nature of this condition is crucial for prompt and accurate diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate

questions.text: Why is atropine mixed with diphenoxylate in combination medications? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To prevent abuse of diphenoxylate

 

Diphenoxylate is an opioid used to treat diarrhea by slowing down bowel movements. However, like other opioids, it carries a risk of abuse, especially if taken in large doses. Atropine, an anticholinergic drug, is mixed with diphenoxylate in subtherapeutic doses to deter misuse. When taken as prescribed, the amount of atropine is too small to cause significant effects. However, if someone tries to abuse diphenoxylate by taking a large number of tablets, the atropine will also accumulate and cause unpleasant side effects such as dry mouth, urinary retention, and blurred vision. These side effects are uncomfortable and discourage further abuse of the medication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atropine decreases the adverse effect of diphenoxylate: This is incorrect because atropine is not added to decrease the adverse effects of diphenoxylate. In fact, when taken in large doses, atropine can add to the side effects rather than diminish them.

 

Option C. To enhance the antidiarrheal effect: While atropine also has anticholinergic properties that can reduce gastrointestinal motility, it is not added for this purpose in the combination. The primary reason for its inclusion is to prevent abuse, not to enhance the antidiarrheal effect.

 

Option D. Atropine produces direct spasmolytic action: Although atropine can reduce spasms in the gastrointestinal tract, it is not included in this combination for its spasmolytic action. The dose of atropine used is subtherapeutic and does not significantly contribute to spasmolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atropine is added to diphenoxylate to prevent the abuse of the opioid component by causing unpleasant side effects if the medication is taken in large doses, thereby discouraging misuse.

questions.text: A 40-year-old electrical worker is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a high-voltage electric shock at work. He reports muscle pain, weakness, and dark-colored urine since the incident. Physical examination reveals tender, swollen muscles in the upper limbs. Laboratory tests show significantly elevated creatine kinase levels. What is the most likely substance found in his urine? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Myoglobin

 

The patient presents with classic signs of rhabdomyolysis - a condition where muscle damage leads to the release of muscle contents into circulation. The key findings supporting this diagnosis are:

 

  • History of high-voltage electric shock (a common cause of rhabdomyolysis)
  • Muscle pain and swelling
  • Dark-colored urine
  • Elevated creatine kinase (indicating muscle damage)

 

In rhabdomyolysis, damaged muscle cells release myoglobin into the bloodstream. Myoglobin is then filtered by the kidneys and appears in urine, giving it a dark or cola-colored appearance. Myoglobin in urine is a hallmark finding in rhabdomyolysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased RBCs in urine: While hematuria can cause dark urine, the presence of elevated CK and muscle symptoms points toward myoglobinuria rather than hematuria. RBCs are not typically released from damaged muscle tissue.

 

Option C. Increased creatine kinase: While CK is elevated in the blood. CK is a marker of muscle damage but is not responsible for urine discoloration.

 

Option D. Increased bilirubin: While hyperbilirubinemia can cause dark urine, this patient's presentation is classic for myoglobinuria. There are no signs of liver disease or hemolysis to suggest bilirubinuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rhabdomyolysis caused by muscle injury (such as electrical shock) leads to myoglobinuria, which causes dark-colored urine along with elevated serum creatine kinase levels.

choices.text: Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent
Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present
Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present

questions.text: During resuscitation, when is the given position? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing present

 

This is the recovery position, indicated in post-op patients who are awake or drowsy or unconscious with pulse and breathing present to prevent aspiration of any secretions or vomit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Unconsciousness with pulse and breathing absent: Means the patient is in cardiac arrest and requires immediate resuscitation measures.

 

Option B. Unconsciousness with pulse present and breathing absent: This is respiratory arrest and rescue breathing or bag-valve-mask ventilation should be initiated to maintain breathing of patient.

 

Option D. Unconsciousness with pulse absent and breathing present: This seems very theoretical because with a lack of circulation, breathing isn’t feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The recovery position is used for an unconscious patient who has a pulse and is breathing to prevent aspiration and maintain airway patency.

questions.text: Ring of Soemmering is seen in? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lens Capsule

 

Ring of Soemmering (Soemmering's ring) is a thick ring of after-cataract that forms between the two layers of the lens capsule. It develops following extracapsular cataract extraction when residual cortical lens material becomes trapped in the peripheral part of the capsular bag. This ring forms behind the iris, enclosed between the anterior and posterior lens capsule, and represents a type of secondary or after-cataract.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wilson's disease: Wilson's disease (hepatolenticular degeneration) is associated with "sunflower cataract" characterized by yellowish-brown dots deposited in the anterior lens capsule in a stellate pattern, and Kayser-Fleischer ring in the cornea, not Soemmering's ring.

 

Option B. Retinitis pigmentosa: This is a degenerative retinal condition that may be associated with posterior subcapsular cataract as a complication, but has no relation to Soemmering's ring formation.

 

Option C. Siderosis bulbi: This condition results from intraocular iron foreign body and causes rusty-brown discoloration of ocular tissues. It has no specific association with Soemmering's ring.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Soemmering's ring represents residual cortical lens material trapped in the peripheral part between the anterior and posterior lens capsule following extracapsular cataract extraction, forming a characteristic ring-like structure behind the iris.

choices.text: It has a half-life of 6 hours.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Technetium-99m (Tc-99m) is NOT correct? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C (It emits Beta radiation)

 

Explanation

 

Technetium-99m (Tc-99m) emits gamma radiation, not beta radiation. The "m" in Tc-99m stands for metastable, which indicates that the nucleus releases gamma rays to reach a stable state. This metastable state decays by emitting low-energy gamma rays rather than beta emission.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It has a half-life of 6 hours - CORRECT The physical half-life of Tc-99m is indeed 6 hours, meaning it loses roughly half of its radioactivity in that time. This relatively short half-life makes it ideal for diagnostic imaging while minimizing patient radiation exposure.

 

Option B. It is derived from Molybdenum - CORRECT Tc-99m is obtained from Molybdenum-99 generators used in nuclear medicine departments, allowing for on-site production of the radioisotope.

 

Option D. Its decay process is isomeric - CORRECT The "m" in Tc-99m stands for metastable, indicating an isomeric transition decay process where the nucleus releases energy (gamma rays) to reach a stable state without changing the number of protons or neutrons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Technetium-99m is the most widely used radioisotope in nuclear medicine due to its ideal 6-hour half-life, low-energy gamma emission (not beta), and versatility in being easily combined with various pharmaceuticals to target specific organs.

questions.text: Which GLUT is present in the skeletal muscle, adipose tissue? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) GLUT 4

 

Explanation:


GLUT 4 is the glucose transporter primarily found in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue. It is an insulin-dependent glucose transporter, meaning that its activity is stimulated by insulin. This allows for the efficient uptake of glucose into cells in response to insulin, helping to regulate blood sugar levels.

 

  • GLUT 2 is insulin-independent and is found in the liver, beta cells of the pancreas, intestines, and kidneys. It helps in the regulation of insulin and plays a key role in glucose sensing.
  • GLUT 5 is primarily involved in fructose transport and is found in the small intestine, kidney, and sperm.
  • GLUT 1 is a ubiquitous glucose transporter found in most tissues, including the brain, erythrocytes, and endothelial cells of the blood-brain barrier. It is responsible for the basal glucose uptake necessary for cellular metabolism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GLUT 2: As stated, GLUT 2 is insulin-independent and is not primarily involved in glucose uptake in skeletal muscle or adipose tissue.

 

Option C. GLUT 5: This transporter is primarily for fructose, not glucose, and is found in the small intestine and other locations, not in skeletal muscle or adipose tissue.

 

Option D. GLUT 1: Although present in many tissues, GLUT 1 is not the primary glucose transporter for skeletal muscle and adipose tissue, which rely on insulin-dependent GLUT 4 for glucose uptake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GLUT 4 is the insulin-dependent glucose transporter present in skeletal muscle and adipose tissue.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive patient presented with a chronic history of watery diarrhea. Histopathology of the duodenum is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the causative organism? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giardia lamblia

 

The histopathology shows trophozoites of Giardia lamblia in the duodenal lumen

 

 

  • Giardia lamblia, also called Giardia duodenalis, is the causative agent of giardiasis. It is the only common pathogenic protozoan found in the duodenum and jejunum of humans.
  • ﻿﻿Infection is acquired by the consumption of water or food contaminated with cysts and may also be transmitted by the faeco-oral route.
  • ﻿﻿It is weakly pathogenic in humans. Secretory IgA and IL-6 are responsible for clearing the infection. Hence, giardiasis usually occurs in immunosuppressed, agammaglobulinemia, or malnourished individuals.
  • ﻿﻿The symptoms include acute or chronic diarrhea, weight loss, malaise, abdominal cramps, distension, and weakness. The stools may be watery, greasy, bulky, or foul-smelling at various times during the course of the infection.
  • ﻿﻿Histopathology of the duodenum reveals several heart-shaped or pear-shaped trophozoites with two equally sized nuclei. The small intestinal morphology is usually normal. However, in heavy infections, there may be villous blunting and intraepithelial infiltrates.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Entamoeba histolytica: This protozoan causes amoebiasis, which is typically associated with bloody diarrhea or dysentery and liver abscesses, not the watery diarrhea commonly seen with Giardia.

 

Option C. Microsporidia: A group of obligate intracellular parasites, known to cause diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals, but they do not produce the trophozoites seen in Giardia infections.

 

Option D. Cryptosporidia: Another protozoan that can cause watery diarrhea, especially in immunocompromised patients, but is identified by different morphological features on histology.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Giardia lamblia is a significant cause of diarrheal disease, especially in settings where water or food might be contaminated. Its unique trophozoites are diagnosable through histopathology, emphasizing the need for awareness of water and food hygiene to prevent its transmission. Treatment typically involves specific anti-protozoal medications, and addressing it effectively is crucial in immunocompromised patients to prevent prolonged symptoms and nutritional deficiencies.

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary lymphoid organ? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thymus

 

Primary lymphoid organs are those where lymphocytes, such as T cells and B cells, develop and mature. The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ responsible for the maturation of T cells. It provides an environment for precursor cells to develop into mature T lymphocytes, which are essential for adaptive immunity. The thymus plays a critical role in establishing central tolerance, ensuring that T cells that react against self-antigens are eliminated.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spleen: The spleen is a secondary lymphoid organ where immune responses are initiated. It filters the blood and houses immune cells but is not involved in the maturation of lymphocytes.

 

Option B. Lymph node: Lymph nodes are secondary lymphoid organs. They filter lymphatic fluid and serve as sites where immune responses are initiated but do not participate in the initial development or maturation of lymphocytes.

 

Option D. Tonsils: Tonsils are also considered secondary lymphoid organs. They play a role in the immune response to pathogens entering through the mouth or nose but are not involved in lymphocyte maturation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ where T cells mature, playing a crucial role in the development of the immune system.

 

Spleen, lymph node and tonsils are considered as secondary lymphoid organs

 

Bone marrow has been considered as an example of both a primary as well as a secondary lymphoid organ.

questions.text: Treatment of this condition in a pregnant female would be? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cryotherapy

 

Explanation:

 

The condition shown in the image is condyloma acuminatum, also known as genital warts, caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).

 

In pregnant females, the treatment options are limited due to potential teratogenic effects of certain medications. Cryotherapy is considered safe and effective for treating genital warts during pregnancy. If cryotherapy is not an option, trichloroacetic acid can also be used safely.

 

If the women is not Pregnant then Podophyllin can be given

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Podophyllin: This medication is teratogenic and should be avoided in pregnant women.

 

Option B. Imiquimod: Safety studies on the use of imiquimod during pregnancy are lacking, so it is also avoided in pregnant females.

 

Option D. Surgical excision: This is generally reserved for very large genital warts, such as Buschke-Löwenstein tumors, and is not the first-line treatment for typical cases of condyloma acuminatum in pregnant females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnant females with condyloma acuminatum, cryotherapy is the preferred treatment due to its safety profile, while teratogenic treatments like podophyllin and those with uncertain safety like imiquimod should be avoided.

questions.text: The vertical and horizontal fracture of nasal septum is: (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chevallet and Jarjaway fracture

 

  • Chevallet fracture - Fracture line runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

 

 

  • Jarjaway fracture - Fracture line starts just above the anterior nasal spine and runs horizontally backward just above the junction of septal cartilage with the vomer.

 

 

Tripod fracture – is zygomatic fracture. Zygoma is separated into three processes. Fracture line passes through zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of maxillary sinus and the zygomaticotemporal suture

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Citelli fracture - This does not pertain to the nasal septum but rather involves other cranial structures.

 

Option C. Tripod fracture - This is a zygomatic fracture where the zygoma is separated into three processes. The fracture line passes through the zygomaticofrontal suture, orbital floor, infraorbital margin and foramen, anterior wall of the maxillary sinus, and the zygomaticotemporal suture, unrelated to the nasal septum fractures.

 

Educational Objective:


The Chevallet and Jarjaway fractures are important classifications in the context of nasal injuries, describing vertical and horizontal fractures of the nasal septum respectively. Understanding these fracture types aids in accurate diagnosis and management of nasal trauma.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 166

questions.text: Scorbutic rosary is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin C

 

Scorbutic rosary is a clinical sign of scurvy, a condition caused by Vitamin C deficiency. Scorbutic rosary refers to the swelling of the costochondral junctions due to impaired collagen synthesis, which occurs in scurvy. Vitamin C is essential for the synthesis of collagen, and its deficiency leads to weakened blood vessels, poor wound healing, and characteristic skeletal abnormalities such as scorbutic rosary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Scorbutic rosary is not associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A deficiency primarily manifests as impaired vision (night blindness), dry skin, and immune system issues.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency leads to rickets, which can cause rachitic rosary, but not scorbutic rosary. Scorbutic rosary is specifically associated with Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy).

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency primarily leads to bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting, not scorbutic rosary. Scorbutic rosary is not associated with Vitamin K deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scorbutic rosary is a clinical sign of scurvy, a condition caused by Vitamin C deficiency.

choices.text: Prescribe an abdominal belt for the daily use
Advise observations and reassessment in 6 months

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient, who underwent midline laparotomy for colonic cancer one month ago, presents with a palpable abdominal bulge at the surgical site. Physical examination reveals a reducible midline incisional hernia of 12cm. What is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schedule for laparoscopic mesh repair 

 

For a patient with a palpable abdominal bulge at the site of a recent surgical incision, indicative of an incisional hernia, management options vary depending on the size of the hernia, symptoms, and the patient's overall health status. 

 

This is a minimally invasive approach that is commonly used for large ventral hernias like in this case. The use of mesh is associated with a lower rate of recurrence compared to suture repair alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Prescribe an abdominal belt for daily use: While an abdominal belt or binder can provide temporary relief and support for a hernia, it does not correct the underlying issue. It is more of a conservative approach and may be considered in patients who are not candidates for surgery.

 

Option C. Advise observations and reassessment in 6 months: Observation may be appropriate for small, asymptomatic hernias or in patients where surgery poses a high risk. However, given the size of the hernia (12 cm), this approach could lead to an increased risk of complications such as incarceration or strangulation.

 

Option D. Laparoscopic closure without mesh: Closing the hernia laparoscopically without mesh is less favored for larger hernias due to higher recurrence rates compared to mesh repair.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with a large, reducible midline incisional hernia is to schedule a laparoscopic mesh repair, which offers a minimally invasive approach with a lower risk of recurrence.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a feature in cerebral palsy? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Flaccid paralysis

 

Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy (CP). It is a feature of lower motor neuron disease.

 

Cerebral palsy is characterized by abnormalities in muscle tone and movement, including -

 

  • Hypertonia (increased muscle tone),
  • Hypotonia (decreased muscle tone),
  • Ataxia (lack of muscle coordination) is also commonly observed in individuals with cerebral palsy.
  • A deficit in the motor, language, and social milestones
  • Microcephaly is a feature of cerebral palsy because of the insult to the developing brain.
  • It is an upper motor neuron disease characterized by rigidity and scissoring gait.
  • Spastic CP is the commonest type (65%)

 

Seen in conditions such as Guillain-Barré syndrome, transverse myelitis, poliomyelitis, and traumatic neuritis, but not typically in cerebral palsy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypotonia: Can be present in cerebral palsy, characterized by low muscle tone.

 

Option B. Microcephaly: Often associated with cerebral palsy due to brain injury or developmental issues.

 

Option C. Ataxia: Characterized by poor balance and coordination, is a common feature of certain types of cerebral palsy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flaccid paralysis is not a feature of cerebral palsy; it is indicative of lower motor neuron disease. Cerebral palsy is characterized by various forms of muscle tone abnormalities and movement disorders.

questions.text: Cherry red spot without organomegaly is seen in which of the following disorders? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tay-Sachs disease

 

Tay-Sachs disease is a lysosomal storage disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme Hexosaminidase A. This condition leads to the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the neurons, which can be observed as a cherry red spot in the macula of the retina. However, unlike other sphingolipidoses, Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the absence of hepatosplenomegaly.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fabry's disease: Fabry's disease is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme α-Galactosidase and is an X-linked recessive disorder. This condition does not typically present with a cherry red spot and is associated with other symptoms such as angiokeratomas and renal complications.

 

Option C. Gaucher's disease: Gaucher's disease results from a deficiency in the enzyme β-Glucosidase. It is typically associated with hepatosplenomegaly, and while cherry red spots can rarely be seen, it is not a common feature of the disease. The presence of hepatosplenomegaly distinguishes it from Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Option D. Von Gierke disease: Von Gierke disease (Glycogen storage disease type I) is not a lysosomal storage disorder or a sphingolipidosis. It is associated with glycogen metabolism and does not present with cherry red spots. This disease also features hepatomegaly, which is not consistent with the condition described in the question.

 

Additional Information

 

  • All sphingolipidoses are autosomal recessive except for Fabry's disease, which is X-linked recessive.
  • All sphingolipidoses are associated with mental retardation except for Gaucher's disease and Fabry's disease.
  • All sphingolipidoses have hepatosplenomegaly except for Tay-Sachs and Krabbe's disease.
  • All sphingolipidoses have a cherry red spot in the eye except for Fabry's and Gaucher's disease.
  • Sphingolipidoses with angiokeratoma include GM1 gangliosidosis and Fabry's disease.
  • Krabbe's disease is also known as Globoid cell leukodystrophy.
  • Sphingolipidoses resembling rheumatoid arthritis or idiopathic juvenile arthritis include Farber's disease.
  • Sphingolipidoses resembling sickle cell crisis include Fabry's disease.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease is characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina without organomegaly.

 

Niemann-Pick disease - characterized by the presence of a cherry red spot in the retina with splenomegaly.

questions.text: During examination of a patient with an intern, the professor asks the patient to invert his foot and he points at the prominent tendon behind the medial malleolus. Which is the tendon being pointed at here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tibialis posterior

 

The tendon behind the medial malleolus that becomes prominent when the foot is inverted is the tibialis posterior tendon. This tendon plays a key role in foot inversion and is located just behind the medial malleolus, making it palpable during this maneuver. It functions to support the arch of the foot and assists in the inversion of the foot, which matches the scenario described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis anterior: This tendon is located on the front of the ankle and is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot but is not located behind the medial malleolus. Hence, it is not the tendon being pointed at in this scenario.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum: This tendon is responsible for extending the toes and dorsiflexing the foot. It is located on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent during inversion.

 

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: This tendon is involved in extending the big toe and dorsiflexing the foot. It is positioned on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent with foot inversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibialis posterior tendon is located behind the medial malleolus and is most prominent when the foot is inverted. This anatomical detail is essential for identifying the tendon during a physical examination.

questions.text: Hepatic avulsions are classified as what grade according to the AAST liver injury scale? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Grade V 

 

Explanation:

 

Hepatic avulsions are classified as Grade V in the AAST liver injury scale. This represents the highest grade of liver injury, reflecting complete detachment of the liver or severe damage to major vascular pedicles. The AAST grading system categorizes liver injuries progressively from minor lacerations to complete avulsion, with Grade V being the most severe form.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grade I - Incorrect Grade I liver injuries only involve minor lacerations less than 1cm in depth. These are superficial injuries that don't involve vascular structures and typically heal without surgical intervention.

 

Option B. Grade II - Incorrect Grade II liver injuries involve lacerations between 1-3cm in depth but don't involve major vascular structures. These moderate injuries are far less severe than complete avulsions.

 

Option C. Grade IV - Incorrect Grade IV liver injuries involve parenchymal disruption affecting 25-75% of one hepatic lobe. While serious, these don't constitute complete avulsion of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatic avulsion represents the most severe form of liver trauma in the AAST classification system and is designated as Grade V. Management of such injuries typically requires damage control surgery with the "4 Ps" approach: Push, Pack, Plug, and Pringle maneuver.

questions.text: Identify this contraceptive: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lippe’s loop

 

Lippe’s loop is a type of non-medicated, first-generation intrauterine device (IUD). It is a plastic coiled device that was widely used in the 1950s and 1960s. It is characterized by its distinctive S-shaped loops, as seen in the image provided.

 

The Lippe's loop does not contain any medication or metal, distinguishing it from other types of IUDs like the Multiload, Mirena, and Copper T 380A, which have additional features or materials to enhance their contraceptive effectiveness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiload: This option is incorrect. The Multiload IUD has serrated edges and typically includes copper wiring on the stem to enhance contraceptive effectiveness.

 

 

Option C. Mirena: This is incorrect. Mirena is a hormonal IUD that releases levonorgestrel and appears white in color. It does not have the coiled shape seen in the image.

 

 

Option D. Copper T 380A: This option is incorrect. The Copper T 380A IUD has copper wires on the branches and the main stem, which is not seen in the provided image.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lippe’s loop is a non-medicated, coiled plastic IUD from the first generation of intrauterine devices.

questions.text: A dead body shows the following finding as in the image. What is the case? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Smothering

 

The image shows signs consistent with smothering, a form of asphyxiation where the airflow is blocked by an external force, usually involving the face or mouth, preventing the person from breathing. In smothering, injuries are typically seen on the face rather than the neck. There may be signs of trauma around the mouth and nose, indicating forceful application, such as abrasions or bruising, which is evident in the provided image. This physical evidence strongly points to smothering as the cause of death, where force is applied directly to the face, blocking the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hanging: Hanging involves the compression of the neck due to the body’s weight pulling down on a ligature around the neck, leading to strangulation and neck injuries. The primary injury site is the neck, not the face, making this option incorrect.

 

Option B. Gagging: Gagging involves inserting a foreign object into the mouth, typically to prevent the person from making noise rather than to kill. Although accidental asphyxia can occur if the object obstructs the airway deeply, injuries are usually minimal and not the result of direct trauma like in smothering. Gagging does not cause the kind of facial trauma visible in the image.
